figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 9 – 13. P. lobata Zaitzev, male terminalia. 9. Lateral view [paratype specimen 13 N 212]. 10. Posterior view (right gonostylus removed) [ 13 N 212]. 11. Dorsal view of epandrium, cercus, and hypoproct [paratype 13 N 214]. 12. Dorsal view of gonocoxites (epandrium removed) [ 13 N 214]. 13. Ventral view (epandrium removed) [ 13 N 214]. Scale bar = 0.1 mm.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 9–13.
P. lobata Zaitzev
, male terminalia. 9. Lateral view [paratype specimen #13N212]. 10. Posterior view (right gonostylus removed) [#13N212]. 11. Dorsal view of epandrium, cercus, and hypoproct [paratype #13N214]. 12. Dorsal view of gonocoxites (epandrium removed) [#13N214]. 13. Ventral view (epandrium removed) [#13N214]. Scale bar = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis and comments.
Phthinia lobata
is distinguished from other Nearctic
Phthinia
species by the presence of only a single apical spine on the gonostylus (this character state shared with
P. meicigama
n. sp.
in the Nearctic region) and a semitransparent, dorsally curved, apically broadly spatulate lobe arising from the inner surface of the gonostylus (
Figs. 12–13
).

Discussion. This taxon has been incorrectly treated in the literature as “
Phthinia tanypus
var. a” by
Fisher ( 1937 ; plate 11 ,
Figs. 8–9
)
and the mistaken identity furthered in
Shaw and Fisher ( 1952 : 193 )
. The male terminalia of this species was also illustrated by
Zaitzev ( 1984 ; Figs. 3.2 , 3.3 )
.

Bionomics.
Phthinia lobata
was previously known only from the holotype collected in Virginia. This species is widespread in the eastern Nearctic with records from Iowa, Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, New York, Quebec, New Hampshire, Virginia, Tennessee, and North Carolina . The seasonal distribution is June–November with the peak of the records June–August. Specimens have been taken in Malaise traps and at elevations of 335m – 1,798m . Many specimens of this species were taken at Ledges State Park, Iowa which includes mixed forests of oak, hickory, maple and basswood.
